Experiments and open research problems are strongly shaped by the 
features=
 of the tools employed. The resulting feasibility of a useful 
solution can=
 become nothing more than a manifestation of the 
limitations of the tool e=
mployed. One-In/One-Out nodes are too 
limiting to explore or "experiment" =
with, to evaluate potential 
alternative activation functions. It is like t=
rying to paint a sunset 
with only black paint on a white canvas. You can i=
dentify primary 
features, but it leaves much to be desired.

Andy Carl


-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Her=
e are my thoughts after reading through this very interesting 
> conversati=
on.
> 
> First, I agree rotation is an important issue for HyperNEAT; 
howe=
ver, 
> I am confident that is can be dealt with.  It's an interesting open=
 
> research problem.
> 
> In any case, there is an important aspect of thi=
s issue that we 
> should also be considering.  The problem is not simply t=
o be able 
to 
> perform a rotation. As Jason's posts imply (and Peter stat=
ed), 
> HyperNEAT and CPPNs should technically already be able to perform 
=
> rotations.  And, in fact, they do.  When I play with God Mode in 
> genet=
ic art I often find weights that when adjusted rotate a part 
of 
> the ima=
ge.  That is not that unusual (although perhaps not as usual 
> as we'd lik=
e either).
> 
> However, that kind of rotation actually *isn't* the type we=
 really 
> need.  The issue is not that a particular shape should be possib=
le 
to 
> rotate some arbitrary angle by changing some weights. Recall that=
 
> CPPNs work by laying out coordinate frames within which higher 
> struc=
utres are situated.  To create a symmetric coordinate frame 
means
> creati=
ng a gradient with *two* sides, both the opposite of each 
> other.  That i=
s, symmetry is not created by flipping a gradient 
from 
> one side to the =
other, but rather by having both sides at the same 
> time.
> 
> Therefore,=
 a rotational coordinate frame should actually contain 
> something akin to=
 a sinusoidal gradient that spreads around a 
circle 
> rather than along a=
 line. Then, structures situated within its 
> coordinate frame would repea=
t in a rotated regular pattern, like 
> petals on a flower (that way you ge=
t rotatonal invariance).  
> 
> Thus what we really want is to be able to f=
eed in a regular 2D 
> coordinate frame and output another coordinate frame=
 that is a sine 
> wave around a circle in 2D as well.  In other words:
> 
=
> f(x,y)=3Da point in this circular petal-like gradient
> 
> Thus we only n=
eed to define a function like that and make it an 
> activation function th=
at takes two distinct inputs.
> 
> However, the problem does remain of wher=
e to control the period of 
> repetition around the circle.
> 
> Actually, =
thinking of it now, what we really want is NOT what I 
just 
> said but rat=
her something a bit different that would solve the 
> problem I just posed:=
 What we want is a function f(x,y) that 
produces 
> a gradient that starts=
 at 0 on e.g. the x axis and then increases 
up 
> to 1 as you rotate aroun=
d the origin to 360 degrees.
> 
> That way, you have a true circular/polar =
coordinate system.  Then 
you 
> can simply run its output into a sine wave=
, and you get the 
> repetition around the circle that I describe above.  T=
hen the 
> frequency of repetition is controlled very easily by varying the=
 
> weight leaving the polar function and entering the sine wave, just 
> a=
s in any normal CPPN!
> 
> So I guess my conclusion is we just need a funct=
ion that converts 
> Cartesian coordinates to a polar angle, and then runni=
ng its output 
> into a periodic activation function will give your nice ro=
tational 
> repetition, which in a neural substrate is rotational invarianc=
e!
> 
> Hmm...so I think this explains in part how to deal with the issue, =

> though maybe not 100% (it doesn't explain what it means if the 
inputs 
=
> to such a polar conversion function are not the base-level x and y, 
> bu=
t I think such cases will actually yield nice localized 
rotational 
> effe=
cts as well).  
> 
> Sorry for writing out my thoughts as they come to me i=
n stream of 
> consciousness- this is a rare case where I'm thinking of ide=
as as I 
> write!
> 
> ken
>

ski"

tion, output results to

> > > > exit and "Y" exit. If there is o=
